1.content: The cotton gin is invented by Eli Whitney, cementing the use of slavery in the South and textile production in the north.

2.content: Robert Fulton builds his first proper steamship, The Clermont, which carried passengers between NYC and Albany, NY along the Hudson River.

3.content: Marbury v. Madison is decided, a landmark case that expressed the power of judicial review for the Supreme Court.

4.content: The Haitian Revolution ends a successful slave revolt, leading to Haitian independence and causing alarm among U.S. slaveowners.

5.content: The Louisiana Purchase nearly doubles the size of the United States and gives the US access to the Mississippi River and the city of New Orleans.

6.content: Jefferson signs the Embargo Act, which ends up punishing US merchants more than the British or the French during the Napoleonic Wars.

7.content: Tecumseh’s attempt to build an Indian confederation in the Ohio River Valley was dashed at the Battle of Tippecanoe.

8.content: Federalists held the Hartford Convention to criticize the Dem-Reps handling of the War of 1812 (results in the  Federalist demise).

9.content: Battle of New Orleans creates a heroic image of General Andrew Jackson...despite the fact that this battle was fought AFTER the peace treaty was signed.

10.content: The Second Bank of the U.S. is chartered for a new 20-year run as a part of Henry Clay’s American System.

11.content: The U.S. economy dips into a panic (recession) after the 2nd Bank of the US tightens lending rules which leads to dropping land prices.

12.content: The Adams-Onis Treaty adds Florida to the United States and gives the US claim to the Oregon Territory.

13.content: The Supreme Court decides that only the federal government has the right to deal with native American tribes in Worcester v. Georgia.

14.content: The Monroe Doctrine serves as a warning to Europeans that the U.S. would not tolerate further attempts at colonization in the Americas.

15.content: The Corrupt Bargain ends the “Era of Good Feelings” and brings John Q. Adams to the presidency… and a very bitter Andrew Jackson.

16.content: The Tariff of “Abominations” is passed, increasing taxes on foreign manufactured products, angering agricultural producers.

17.content: Andrew Jackson is elected president, ushering in the Second Two-Party System. His “populist” campaign courts the “common man” vote.

18.content: French writer Alexis de Tocqueville begins his visit to the U.S., leading to his classic work “Democracy in America”.

19.content: Responding to the Nullification Crisis, Jackson’s Force Bill threatens South Carolina to comply with federal law. Henry Clay’s Compromise Tariff prevents civil war.

20.content: Indian Removal Act is signed by Andrew Jackson.

21.content: Treaty of New Echota was agreed to by a minority of unelected Cherokee, handing over land in Georgia for reservations in Oklahoma.

22.content: The Trail of Tears begins a forced evacuation of Cherokee from their land east of the Mississippi River to present-day Oklahoma.

23.content: Jackson issues his Bank Veto, four years ahead of the bank’s expiration.  The Whig Party forms soon after.

24.content: An economic recession hits the U.S. after Jackson stashes U.S. money in his “pet banks”, leading to a lending frenzy...and eventual panic.

25.content: The Lowell System is at its height, which uses rivers to fuel textile mills in Massachusetts, employing young women. Example of the rise of the market economy

26.content: Minstrel shows first gain popularity (in this decade) as white men in black face caricaturize  African-Americans as Jim Crow, Zip Coon, and Mamie.

27.content: The Know Nothing Party does well in state and local elections this year, when nativist sentiments were high due to high Irish & German immigration.

28.content: The Erie Canal is completed, connecting New York City to the Great Lakes.

29.content: Samuel Morse is awarded a patent on an electromagnetic telegraph, a major breakthrough in the communication revolution.

30.content: Ms. Sadlon is crowned homecoming queen while in high school; all is right in the world.

31.content: The first railroad connecting Chicago to points west opens in this year. Over the next 10 years, Chicago becomes a major trade city.

32.content: Missouri Compromise creates rules for slavery in states carved out of the Louisiana Purchase territory.
